title: Beyond Mice and Menus
abstract: Dr. Grosz gives an engaging lecture on the history of computers and how she believes the world of computers should move forward and beyond "mice and menus."

title: Architecture for Cyber Security
speaker_position: Forrest G. Hamrick Professor of Engineering and Professor of Electrical Engineering
abstract: Dr. Lee makes the case for the importance of cybersecurity in order to secure democracy and civilized life.

title: Policy Implications on Bounded Rationality
speaker_position: Sir Isaac Wolfson Professor of Public Finance
abstract: Dr. Sheshinski analyzes self-selection models, when individuals know more about themselves than it is possible for governments to know, and shows that it may be socially optimal to limit and sometimes to eliminate individual choice.

title: Accident, Luck and Serendipity in Historical Research
abstract: The influence of fortuitous elements on individual pieces of work seems almost self-evident. Dr. McClellan explores the implications of these accidental circumstances for historiography and historical research.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia: An Antique Land and a Ravaged Past
speaker_position: George G. Cameron Professor of Ancient Near Eastern Civilizations
abstract: Dr. Michalowski gives a talk focusing on the plundering of the National Museum in Baghdad by US forces during the Second Gulf War.

title: Contexts of Iraqi Looting
speaker_institution: University of California at San Diego
abstract: Dr. Adams presents a historical context for the looting of museums, archives, and libraries by the US invading forces in Iraq.
lcsh_topic: Iraq, Politics and government; Looting; Mesopotamia

title: Portraiture and the Development of African American Identity in the 19th Century

lcsh_name_personal: Williams, Moses, 1777-ca. 1825; Peale, Charles Willson, 1741-1827; Peale, Rembrandt, 1778-1860

title: Expanding the Mainstream: Romare Bearden Revisited

title: Megalithomania: Obelisks and Empire in Papal Rome
abstract: Dr. Collins speaks on the obelisks of Rome: how they were removed from elsewhere in the Roman Empire and how they represent imperial Rome.

title: Evolution of Retroviruses: Fossils in our DNA
speaker_position: Professor of Molecular Biology and Microbiology
abstract: Dr. Edwin Kilbourne introduces Dr. John Coffin, who presents a talk on viruses and how they evolve very quickly.

symposium: Virus Paleontology, Disease and Evolution
title: Circe, Cassandra and Trojan Pigs: Xenotransplantation
abstract: Dr. Weiss describes himself as a Cassandra figure in microbiology. He talks about his reservations of transplanting animal parts into humans.

symposium: Virus Paleontology, Disease and Evolution
title: Can Persisting Viruses Drive Human Evolution?
abstract: Viruses have always been with us. Dr. Villarreal talks about what this persistance means for human evolution.

symposium: Virus Paleontology, Disease and Evolution
title: When Genes Go Walkabout: Viruses in the Blueprint
abstract: Greg Bear offers a personal view of biology, specifically evolution and Charles Darwin.

title: Picturing Nature in the Age of Enlightenment

title: The Linnaean Enterprise: Past, Present and Future
